pullrequest.title: Add carriage return support to outputbox

content.raw:
This is great! I use tqdm too so that's really nice.

The application of formatting to the whole block is a loss in functionality - can it be avoided? Usually in practice formatting is not mixed on a line, but I'd rather not require it. With this change, a subprocess launched via zprocess that writes to stdout and then stderr without a linebreak in between will have the stdout appear red too.
content.html:
This is great! I use tqdm too so that's really nice.

The application of formatting to the whole block is a loss in functionality - can it be avoided? Usually in practice formatting is not mixed on a line, but I'd rather not require it. With this change, a subprocess launched via zprocess that writes to stdout and then stderr without a linebreak in between will have the stdout appear red too.

pullrequest.title: Add carriage return support to outputbox

content.raw:
Good catch!

Fixed. Here’s some stderr appearing in the middle of a tqdm, with correct colours. Scrolling seems to work fine.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/Rg5nLg/images/1555001294-Capture.PNG)
content.html:
Good catch!

Fixed. Here’s some stderr appearing in the middle of a tqdm, with correct colours. Scrolling seems to work fine.

pullrequest.title: Add carriage return support to outputbox

content.raw: Thanks Lincoln! Merged. I'll make a new issue to coordinate with Phil regarding the next PyPI release.
content.html: Thanks Lincoln! Merged. I'll make a new issue to coordinate with Phil regarding the next PyPI release.

pullrequest.title: Add carriage return support to outputbox

content.raw:
qtutils 2.2.2 includes this change and has been released on PyPI. You can upgrade with ``pip install qtutils==2.2.2``.

(the .2 is because I messed up the release and PyPI doens't let you reuse version numbers under any circumstances. It would otherwise have been 2.2.0)
content.html:
qtutils 2.2.2 includes this change and has been released on PyPI. You can upgrade with pip install qtutils==2.2.2.

(the .2 is because I messed up the release and PyPI doens't let you reuse version numbers under any circumstances. It would otherwise have been 2.2.0)
